page.title: 09Ecology 4: Birds, Trees
page.content:
BIRDS: Summer visitors also breeding include stonechat, wheatear, redstart, spotted flycatcher, cuckoo, swallow, housemartin, sandmartin, swift, curlew & lapwing. The oyster catcher is also seen, but is not known to be breeding.
TREES: The ash tree predominates, with rowan, sycamore, silver birch, beech, oak, aspen and elm. Larch is used in shelter-belts. Hawthorn, blackthorn and holly hedges are common. Hazel and ash, once coppiced for the bobbin mill grow in the Howk.
NATIONAL PARK: Most of the area lies within the Lake District National Park and is controlled by its Special Plan- ning Board. The Board's main purposes are conservation of local wildlife, habitat and historic buildings and of the established farming pattern.
